instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.P5VG3S_PGOOD: What is P5VG3S_PGOOD? P5VG3S_PGOOD is a signal that indicates that the PP5V_G3S power rail is functioning properly. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, does not boot, 20v 70mA
threads.message:
Hey there :)

I got this board with no liquid spill or any other signs, no knocked off components.

Initially it used to start with 20v 150-300mA, staying for a few seconds and then bootlooping.
I tried DFU mode, which it successfully enters, however it failed every single attempt to recover with "Failed to restore device in DFU mode"
[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>PXL_20220221_114336114</SIGNAL>.jpg"]60431[/ATTACH]

After several unsuccessful attempts, it started giving a different error:
[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>PXL_20220221_114800906</SIGNAL>.jpg"]60432[/ATTACH]

Then I placed it back on the bench and now it only uses 40-70mA without any bootlooping.
I already took some voltage measurements, please lemme know your thoughts.

Big coils are at:
L7670 - 5V
L7690 - 3.3V
L7030 - 8.6V
All other big coils at 0V

<SIGNAL>PP1V_PRIM</SIGNAL>                                          0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S5</SIGNAL>                                       0V
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_PGOOD</SIGNAL>                                1.7V
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL>                                               0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL>                                             0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>                               0V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL>                                   12.6v

<SIGNAL>PP_SSD0_S4E2_VPP</SIGNAL>                             1.30-2.60V (pulsing)
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0_S4E2_VDD_PLL</SIGNAL>             0.90V
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>                            2.50V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCQ_ANI_SSD0</SIGNAL>                             1.80V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_IO_SSD0</SIGNAL>                                   1.80V
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL>                                         0.90V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_S4E2_ANI1_VREF</SIGNAL>                       0.90V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_S4E2_ANI0_VREF</SIGNAL>                       0.90V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0_S4E2_AVDD18_PLL</SIGNAL>      1.80V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0_S4E2_PCI_AVDD_H</SIGNAL>       1.80V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, does not boot, 20v 70mA
threads.message:
Botlooping could be caused by short on some secondary supply.
Did you check resistance to ground at all big coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, does not boot, 20v 70mA
threads.message:
Resistance to ground is 5-30Ω on all the CPU coils and 62Ω at L7702.

The board is no longer bootlooping after failed DFU attempts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, does not boot, 20v 70mA
threads.message: I suppose something wrong with SSD and DFU cannot write the firmware partition.
